Carbohydrates.question: What three elements are found in all carbohydrates? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Carbon (C)
Hydrogen (H)
Oxygen (O)

Carbohydrates.question: Define a monosaccharide. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A single (simple) sugar unit (monomer)

Carbohydrates.question: Give two examples of monosaccharides. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Glucose
Fructose
Galactose

Carbohydrates.question: What is the molecular formula of glucose? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: C₆H₁₂O₆

Carbohydrates.question: Explain the difference between α- and β-glucose. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: They are isomers: differ in orientation of H and OH on carbon 1
α-glucose has OH below ring, β-glucose above ring

Carbohydrates.question: What type of reaction joins monosaccharides to form disaccharides? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Condensation reaction

Carbohydrates.question: What bond is formed when two monosaccharides join? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Glycosidic bond

Carbohydrates.question: What are the three disaccharides students must know in OCR biology? [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Maltose (glucose + glucose)
Lactose (glucose + galactose)
Sucrose (glucose + fructose)

Carbohydrates.question: Describe hydrolysis in terms of carbohydrate breakdown. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Addition of water
Breaks glycosidic bonds to yield monosaccharides

Carbohydrates.question: State the formula for a disaccharide in terms of the monosaccharide formula. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: (CₙH₂ₙOₙ)₂ – H₂O

Carbohydrates.question: Name two polysaccharides formed from α-glucose. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Starch
Glycogen

Carbohydrates.question: Describe the structure of amylose. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Unbranched
1→4 glycosidic bonds
Coiled (spiral) structure

Carbohydrates.question: Describe the structure of amylopectin. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Branched
1→4 and 1→6 glycosidic bonds
Side branches allow rapid hydrolysis

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how the structure of glycogen relates to its function. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Highly branched (1→4 and 1→6 bonds)
Compact for storage
Many ends allow rapid glucose release

Carbohydrates.question: Describe the structure of cellulose. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: β-glucose units
1→4 glycosidic bonds
Straight, unbranched chains forming microfibrils

Carbohydrates.question: Explain why cellulose is strong and suitable for cell walls. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Straight chains held by hydrogen bonds
Microfibrils provide tensile strength
Insoluble – maintains cell structure

Carbohydrates.question: State one function of glucose in living organisms. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Energy source
Building block for larger molecules

Carbohydrates.question: Give one use of starch in plants. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Energy storage

Carbohydrates.question: Explain why polysaccharides are better for storage than monosaccharides. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Insoluble (no osmotic effect)
Compact storage
Reservoir of glucose units without affecting water potential

Carbohydrates.question: Outline how reducing sugars can be detected. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Benedict’s test (blue → red precipitate)
Requires heating

Carbohydrates.question: Why is sucrose a non-reducing sugar? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: No free aldehyde or ketone group
Does not react directly with Benedict’s reagent unless hydrolysed

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how to test for non-reducing sugars like sucrose. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Hydrolyse (e.g. heat with dilute acid)
Neutralise solution
Carry out Benedict’s test to detect the released reducing monosaccharides

Carbohydrates.question: Compare and contrast starch and cellulose. [5 marks]
mark_scheme: Starch composed of α-glucose; cellulose of β-glucose
Starch has helical (amylose) and branched (amylopectin) forms; cellulose is straight chains
Starch used for storage; cellulose for structural support
Amylose/amylopectin insoluble but digestible by animals; cellulose insoluble and indigestible

Carbohydrates.question: Explain the roles of hydrogen bonding in cellulose structure and function. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Hydrogen bonds form between hydroxyl groups on adjacent chains
Bind chains into microfibrils
Provide tensile strength
Prevent breakdown in aqueous environments

Carbohydrates.question: Describe the primary structure of glycogen. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: α-glucose units
Joined by 1→4 glycosidic bonds
1→6 glycosidic linkages at branching points

Carbohydrates.question: How does the branching in glycogen enhance its function? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: More branch ends for enzyme action
Faster glucose release

Carbohydrates.question: Explain why polysaccharides are often used as energy storage molecules. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Compact & insoluble
No osmotic effect
Can store large amount of glucose
Easily hydrolysed when energy is needed

Carbohydrates.question: What is meant by the term 'polysaccharide'? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A polymer of many monosaccharide units

Carbohydrates.question: Give one biological role of glycogen. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Animal energy storage (especially in liver and muscle)

Carbohydrates.question: State how maltose is formed. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Two glucose molecules joined via condensation forming a glycosidic bond

Carbohydrates.question: Why is maltose a reducing sugar? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Has a free aldehyde group on one glucose unit
Can reduce Benedict's reagent

Carbohydrates.question: Describe an advantage of branching in polysaccharides like glycogen. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: More ends available for enzyme attack
Faster mobilization of glucose

Carbohydrates.question: Explain why plants store starch instead of glucose. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Starch is insoluble (avoids osmotic problems)
Compact energy storage
Glucose is soluble and would raise osmotic pressure

Carbohydrates.question: Outline the difference in solubility between monosaccharides and polysaccharides. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Monosaccharides are water soluble
Polysaccharides are generally insoluble

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how the ring structure of glucose contributes to its function. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Ring structure stable in aqueous solution
Enzymes can specifically act on glycosidic bonds between ring units
Soluble for transport

Carbohydrates.question: Distinguish between reducing and non-reducing sugars with examples. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Reducing sugars can reduce Benedict’s reagent (e.g. glucose, maltose)
Non-reducing sugars cannot unless hydrolysed first (e.g. sucrose)

Carbohydrates.question: Describe why cellulose cannot be digested by most animals. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: β-glycosidic bonds require cellulase enzyme
Most animals lack cellulase

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how the test for reducing sugars works. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Reducing sugar donates electrons to blue Cu²⁺ in Benedict’s solution
Forms red Cu₂O precipitate

Carbohydrates.question: Write one structural difference between amylose and amylopectin. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Amylose is unbranched; amylopectin is branched

Carbohydrates.question: Explain why glucose is transported in blood as monosaccharide. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Soluble in blood plasma
Small enough to cross membranes for respiration

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how condensation reactions are involved in carbohydrate metabolism. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Condensation joins monosaccharides by removing water
Forms glycosidic bonds in di- and polysaccharides

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how hydrolysis reactions are important after digestion. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Hydrolysis adds water to break glycosidic bonds
Releases monosaccharides for absorption

Carbohydrates.question: State one function of cellulose in plants. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Strength/support in plant cell walls

Carbohydrates.question: Give a similarity and a difference between starch and glycogen. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Similarity: both are α-glucose polymers used for storage
Difference: glycogen is more highly branched than starch

Carbohydrates.question: Why are polysaccharides suited for long‑term energy storage? [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Insoluble (avoids osmotic issues)
Compact storage
Large molecule can store many glucose units
Branches allow rapid release

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how the physical properties of starch relate to its role. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Insoluble – no osmotic effect
Compact coiled or branched structure suitable for storage
Easily hydrolysed when energy needed

Carbohydrates.question: Explain the function of reducing sugars in metabolism. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Provide energy via respiration
React in tests enabling detection in diagnostics

Carbohydrates.question: Compare and contrast the structure and function of starch and cellulose in plants. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Both are polysaccharides composed of glucose monomers
Starch is made of α-glucose; cellulose is made of β-glucose
Starch has branched (amylopectin) and unbranched (amylose) forms; cellulose forms straight, unbranched chains
Cellulose chains form hydrogen bonds → microfibrils; starch coils into compact helical structures
Starch functions as energy storage; cellulose provides structural support in cell walls
Starch is digestible by animals; cellulose is indigestible due to β-1,4 linkages

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how the structure of glycogen makes it an effective energy storage molecule in animals. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Made of α-glucose units linked by 1→4 and 1→6 glycosidic bonds
Highly branched – provides multiple ends for rapid glucose release
Compact – fits into small storage spaces
Insoluble – does not affect osmotic balance or water potential
Easily hydrolysed – enzymes can quickly break down glycogen to glucose
Stored in liver and muscle tissues – readily available energy source

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how disaccharides and polysaccharides are formed and broken down in biological systems. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Formed by condensation reactions between monosaccharides
Glycosidic bonds form during condensation; water is released
Examples: glucose + glucose → maltose (disaccharide)
Polysaccharides form from repeated condensation of monosaccharides (e.g. starch, glycogen)
Broken down by hydrolysis – water is added to break glycosidic bonds
Enzymes such as amylase and maltase catalyse hydrolysis in digestion

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how you would test for the presence of reducing and non-reducing sugars in a solution. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Add Benedict’s reagent to solution and heat in water bath
Colour change from blue to brick-red indicates reducing sugar
If no change, sugar may be non-reducing (e.g. sucrose)
Hydrolyse sample by heating with dilute acid (e.g. HCl)
Neutralise with sodium hydrogen carbonate
Repeat Benedict’s test – red precipitate indicates non-reducing sugar was present

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how the structure of cellulose contributes to its function in plant cell walls. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Made from β-glucose monomers joined by 1→4 glycosidic bonds
Every other glucose is flipped → allows straight, unbranched chains
Chains held together by hydrogen bonds → form microfibrils
Microfibrils are strong and form a criss-crossed network
Provides tensile strength to resist osmotic pressure and maintain cell shape
Insoluble – does not dissolve in water and provides long-lasting support

Cells.question: Name two organelles found in eukaryotic cells that are not in prokaryotic cells. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Nucleus
Mitochondria
Endoplasmic reticulum
Golgi apparatus
Chloroplasts

Cells.question: State the function of the nucleus. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Contains genetic material (DNA)
Controls cell activities by regulating gene expression

Cells.question: What is the role of ribosomes? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Site of protein synthesis

Cells.question: Give one difference between the cell wall of plants and prokaryotic cells. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Plants: made of cellulose; Prokaryotic: made of peptidoglycan

Cells.question: Define ‘resolution’ in microscopy. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Minimum distance two points can be separated and still seen as separate

Cells.question: Explain why electron microscopes give higher resolution than light microscopes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Electrons have shorter wavelength than light
Therefore can resolve objects closer together

Cells.question: Describe one advantage and one disadvantage of using electron microscopes compared to light microscopes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Advantage: higher resolution
Disadvantage: expensive; complex preparation; cannot image live cells

Cells.question: Explain the function of the plasma membrane in cells. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Controls movement of substances in and out of cells
Maintains internal environment

Cells.question: What are phospholipids and what is their role in the cell membrane? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Molecules with hydrophilic head and hydrophobic tails
Form bilayer; control permeability

Cells.question: Describe the fluid mosaic model of membrane structure. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Phospholipid bilayer forms fluid matrix
Proteins float like mosaic; channel, carrier, receptor
Cholesterol molecules add stability

Cells.question: Compare facilitated diffusion and active transport. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Facilitated diffusion uses protein channels; passive (no ATP)
Active transport uses carrier proteins; requires ATP
Active can move substances against concentration gradient

Cells.question: Describe how water moves across cell membranes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: By osmosis
Movement from high to low water potential through partially permeable membrane

Cells.question: How does increasing surface area to volume ratio affect diffusion in cells? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Larger surface area relative to volume increases rate of diffusion
Reduces distance for substances to travel

Cells.question: Explain how gas exchange surfaces in multicellular organisms are adapted for efficient diffusion. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Large surface area
Thin layers
Steep concentration gradient maintained

Cells.question: State one example of a specialized cell in animals and its function. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Neutrophil – engulfs pathogens
Red blood cell – carries oxygen

Cells.question: Give one difference between animal and plant cells. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Animal cells lack cell wall, chloroplasts; have centrioles

Cells.question: Define ‘differentiation’ in cells. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Process by which cells become specialized in structure and function

Cells.question: Explain why muscle cells contain many mitochondria. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Muscle cells need ATP for contraction
Mitochondria are site of aerobic respiration

Cells.question: Describe the structure and function of a root hair cell. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Long extension (root hair) increases surface area
Thin-walled for water/mineral absorption

Cells.question: What is meant by the term ‘multicellular’? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Organism composed of many cells with division of labor

Cells.question: Explain how stem cells differ from differentiated cells. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Stem cells are unspecialized and can divide
Can differentiate into multiple cell types

Cells.question: Describe how sodium ions are transported out of cells via active transport. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Carrier protein binds sodium ions
ATP provides energy; changes shape
Sodium released outside cell against gradient

Cells.question: Explain the role of carrier proteins in glucose uptake into cells. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Carrier specific for glucose binds it
Changes conformation to allow glucose into cell
Down concentration gradient (facilitated diffusion) or uses ATP in co-transport with sodium

Cells.question: Compare prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells in terms of genetic material. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Prokaryotic: one circular DNA molecule free in cytoplasm
Eukaryotic: chromosomes in a nucleus

Cells.question: Explain how phospholipids contribute to the impermeability of the cell membrane to water-soluble substances. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Hydrophobic tails repel water-soluble molecules
Only small non-polar molecules pass freely

Cells.question: Describe how the structure of the cell surface membrane allows cell communication. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Proteins act as receptors for signals
Glycoproteins act as cell markers
Allows cells to respond to signals (e.g., hormones)

Cells.question: Outline two ways in which the structure of red blood cells is suited to their function. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Biconcave shape increases surface area
No nucleus to leave more space for hemoglobin
Flexible – fits capillaries

Cells.question: Explain why most cells are microscopic in size. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Large surface area to volume ratio is needed
Ensures sufficient diffusion for substances

Cells.question: Describe the role of cholesterol in the cell membrane. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Fits between phospholipids
Stabilises membrane; reduces permeability to small water-soluble molecules

Cells.question: Explain how the rough endoplasmic reticulum is involved in protein synthesis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Ribosomes on RER synthesise proteins
Proteins folded and transported to Golgi apparatus

Cells.question: Describe the function of lysosomes. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Contain digestive enzymes; break down waste and pathogens

Cells.question: Explain why a high surface area:volume ratio is more efficient for exchange surfaces in the lungs. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: More surface area allows more gas exchange
Thin alveolar walls and high capillary density maintain gradient

Cells.question: Describe the function of the cytoskeleton. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Provides structure and shape
Enables movement of organelles or whole cell

Cells.question: Explain how diffusion across cell membranes can be affected by temperature. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Higher temperature increases kinetic energy
More frequent collisions with membrane
Increases rate of diffusion

Cells.question: Outline the advantages of a light microscope. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Can view live cells
Inexpensive and portable

Cells.question: Compare the roles of rough and smooth endoplasmic reticulum. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Rough ER: synthesises proteins (has ribosomes)
Smooth ER: synthesises lipids and detoxifies

Cells.question: Explain how surface proteins assist in cell recognition by the immune system. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Glycoproteins on surface act as antigens or markers
Recognised by antibodies or immune cells
Trigger immune response

Cells.question: Describe how ion channels differ from carrier proteins. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Ion channels form pores allowing passive movement of ions
Carrier proteins bind and transport specific molecules; may use ATP

Cells.question: Explain the importance of differentiation in the development of complex organisms. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Specialised cells perform specific functions more efficiently
Allows division of labour
Enables multicellular organisms to develop tissues/organs

Cells.question: Describe how gas exchange surfaces are maintained in active tissues. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Maintains steep concentration gradient via blood flow
Ventilation replenishes gases
Large surface area maintained (e.g. alveoli)

Cells.question: Explain how plasmolysis occurs in plant cells. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Loss of water by osmosis
Cell membrane pulls away from cell wall
Cell becomes flaccid
